awd_abstract_narration:
Matching theory is an area in discrete mathematics that asks for the minimum number of elements needed to intersect all the sets in a given family of sets. Such a minimal set of elements is called a cover of the family. Many practical problems can be formulated as questions about covers of families of sets that arise in different contexts (for example, subscribers in a social network, geographical areas, biological cells). An example from public health is: How many medical clinics should be placed in a given state, and where, so that every resident has a clinic within 50 miles of home? Here the sets in question are disks of radius 50 miles centered at every household, and clinics are to be placed in every point of a cover.  As apparent from this example, the questions studied in matching theory can be basic and intuitive, easily formulated, and are combinatorial, or discrete, in flavor. Nevertheless, they are often notoriously difficult to answer and require sophisticated tools from different areas of mathematics (such as algebra, probability, and topology) for their solution. This project focuses on developing improved methods (primarily topological ones) to approach several fundamental open problems in matching theory. As the methods developed come from other areas of mathematics, this project also contributes to building bridges between different branches of mathematics, making problems in one branch amenable to the tools of another. The project involves a graduate student in the research.
 
This project studies matching theory in abstract finite hypergraphs, as well as hypergraphs arising from geometrical structures, whose edges are (generally, infinite) sets in a Euclidean space. Two intriguing longstanding conjectures on abstract hypergraphs motivate this project: one (Gyárfás-Lehel) concerns covers of hypergraphs consisting of cross-intersecting families of sets, and the other (Tuza) deals with covers of hypergraphs of triangles in graphs. Both conjectures received considerable attention over the years, mostly using elementary approaches, which now seem insufficient for their solution. One goal of this project is to develop new tools from other areas of mathematics for tackling these conjectures and related problems. Hypergraphs arising from geometrical structures are of special interest to researchers, as they appear in many different practical applications; consequently, questions in matching theory of geometrical hypergraphs have been widely studied (under different names) for decades. Within this direction, the project focuses on a conjecture of Wegner on covers of families of axis-parallel rectangles in the plane (and families of axis-parallel boxes in higher dimensions). The second main goal of this project is to develop a topological method in higher dimensions for the resolution of Wegner’s conjecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All the main objectives of the project have been fulfilled.

First, the project had high impact in research and advancing knowledge in the area of matching theory of graphs and hypergraphs. Significant research results in the area have been proven as part of the project, and to this end, a novel topological method has been developed. This method has further applications in other areas of research, such as discrete geometry and game theory. The research results proven as part of this project were published, or submitted for publication, in 17 papers, all in top-tier peer-reviewd journals.

Here is a summary of most significant research results: 

1. A conjecture of Eckhoff from 1993 concerning the line piercing numbers of certain families of convex set in the plane was proved. The proof involved a novel topological method that was since then used in various other significant results, by the PI as well as by other researchers.

2. A conjecture of Soberon was proved. This involved proving a new polytopal sparse extension of the topological KKM theorem, that has applications to piercing numbers, matching theory, mass partition, fair division and other areas. 

3. A conjecture of Bárány and Kalai that generalizes the Tverberg theorem, was proved for certain families of polytopes. To this end we proved a new extension of the topological Borsuk-Ulam theorem, that is likely to have applications in other areas as well. 

4. A conjecture of Sivaraman was proved in a special case.

5. It was shown that if a finite family of compact convex sets in the plane has matching number p, then it is pierced by p/2+1 lines. To this end, a generalization of the topological method introduced in (1) was used. This raises an interesting question concerning the hyperplane piercing number of families of convex sets in R^d with matching number p.

6. A question of Alon concerning K_5-codes was answered. We also introduced the function g(G,H) which is the minimum number of colors needed to edge-color a graph G so that every copy of H has an odd color class, and prove tight bounds on it for certain pairs G,H. 

7. The KKM theorem is a fundamental result in fixed-point theory from 1929, which has seen numerous extensions and applications. A paper surveying old and recent generalizations of the KKM theorem and their applications in the areas of piercing numbers, mass partition, fair division, and matching theory was written. 

The project had major impact in the area of training students and postdocs and education. As part of this project the PI advised three PhD students and ten undergraduate students, and mentored two postdocs. In addition the PI organized and led two summer schools for graduate students and postdocs:

  • MSRI Summer Graduate School on “Topological Methods for the Discrete Mathematician” (together with Pavle Blagojevi ́c and Florian Frick) – Summer 2022, and 
  • Graduate School on “Topological Methods in Discrete Mathematics” at the Free University of Berlin (together with Pavle Blagojevi ́c and Florian Frick) – May-June 2022.

Finally, the project had broader impact on society as well. As part of this project the PI was the co-leader and organizer of the Sonia Kovalevsky Day at her institute (Iowa State University; 2022, 2023, 2024). The Sonia Kovalevsky Day is an annual event for middle school girls and their math teachers organized by the Department of Mathematics at Iowa State University, which aimed to increase middle school girls’ interest in mathematics, assist them in the transition between middle school and high school mathematics, encourage them to pursue careers in STEM disciplines, and to develop more extensive cooperation with middle schools and high schools in their area. Participants in those events have engaged in hands-on activities through a series of workshops on exciting math topics.
